snippet: Any malicious sexual contact by prison guards against prisoners may be a constitutional violation, a federal appeals court ruled on Tuesday, noting how society’s standards of decency have evolved.
abstract: Unanimous decision by three-judge panel on federal appeals court rules that prisoners who are subjected to any kind of malicious sexual conduct by prison guards may have had their constitutional rights violated; decision allows furthering of case involving paroled prisoners James Crawford and Thaddeus Corley, who complained about sexually demeaning actions of Officer Simon Prindle while they were imprisoned at Eastern Correctional Facility.
lead_paragraph: Any malicious sexual contact by prison guards against prisoners may be a constitutional violation, a federal appeals court ruled on Tuesday, noting how society’s standards of decency have evolved.

headline.main: Any Sexual Abuse by Guards May Violate Inmates’ Rights, Court Says
headline.print_headline: Any Sexual Abuse by Guards May Violate Inmates’ Rights, U.S. Appeals Court Says
